description: Ensures select element has an accessible name
help: Select element must have an accessible name
html: [['<select id="CountryCode" name="CountryCode" required="" field="">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix all of the following:\n  Form element has explicit <label> that is hidden']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<select id="CountryCode" name="CountryCode" required="" field="">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Select element missing descriptive label. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
WCAG 2.1 Success Criteria 4.1.2 requires that form controls are associated with labels that describe their purpose. The code snippet provided has a form control named "CountryCode" without an associated descriptive label. Below is the updated code snippet with the necessary label added:

```html
<select id="CountryCode" name="CountryCode" required>
    <option value="">Select Country</option>
    <!-- Add your country options here -->
</select>
<label for="CountryCode">Select Country</label>
```

This code snippet includes the `<label>` element with the `for` attribute set to the same value as the `id` of the `<select>` element. This associates the label with the select control, fulfilling the requirement to provide a descriptive label. When a user accesses the form, they will see the text "Select Country" as the label for the "CountryCode" select control, enhancing accessibility for users who rely on screen readers or other assistive technologies.

description: Landmarks should have a unique role or role/label/title (i.e. accessible name) combination
help: Ensures landmarks are unique
html: [['<aside class="container  tooltip-below ">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  The landmark must have a unique aria-label, aria-labelledby, or title to make landmarks distinguishable']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<aside class="container  tooltip-below ">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Multiple landmarks of the same type should have unique and descriptive labels. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
The source code you provided, `<aside class="container tooltip-below ">`, seems to be lacking the necessary semantic markup to create a landmark that can be uniquely labeled. This is crucial for accessibility, as it helps screen reader users and others with disabilities navigate a webpage by identifying different sections. 

To address this issue, you can wrap your content inside a `main`, `article`, `section`, or `aside` element, depending on what the content represents. Additionally, you can add a `aria-label` attribute to provide a unique and descriptive label for the landmark.

Here's an example using an `aside` element:

```html
<aside class="container tooltip-below" aria-label="Additional Information">
    <!-- Your content goes here -->
</aside>
```

In this example, `aria-label="Additional Information"` provides a unique and descriptive label for the `aside` element. Make sure the label is meaningful and accurately reflects the content within the `aside` element.

Remember to use the appropriate semantic HTML5 elements based on the content's purpose. For example:

- Use `<main>` if the section contains the main content of the page.
- Use `<article>` if the section contains self-contained content that could be re-used elsewhere.
- Use `<section>` for a topic that could stand alone but is part of a larger topic.

After making these changes, ensure that your website passes an accessibility audit tool like the WAVE Widget or the Google Lighthouse Accessibility Audit to confirm that the accessibility issues have been resolved.

prompts_baseline_one:
Given the following source code "<g id="WeekdayShort" class="1" fill="rgb(95,99,104)" font-size="14" font-family="Google Sans Text" font-style="normal" font-weight="500" aria-label="TUE" transform="matrix(2,0,0,2,50,20.66699981689453)" opacity="1" style="display: block;">
<g id="Title" class="1" fill="rgb(95,99,104)" font-size="14" font-family="Google Sans Text" font-style="normal" font-weight="500" aria-label="Weekly standup" transform="matrix(2,0,0,2,127,36.66699981689453)" opacity="1" style="display: block;">
<g id="Time" class="1" fill="rgb(255,255,255)" font-size="14" font-family="Google Sans Text" font-style="normal" font-weight="400" aria-label="11 AM – 12 PM" transform="matrix(2,0,0,2,109,76.66699981689453)" opacity="1" style="display: block;">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Multiple elements share the same id attribute. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Certainly! The issue you've pointed out is that there are multiple elements sharing the same `id` attribute value, which is against the best practices for accessibility, as it can cause confusion for screen readers and other assistive technologies. According to the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1, each HTML element should have a unique `id` attribute. To address this, we'll assign unique `id` attributes to each element.

Here's the corrected code:

```html
<!-- Original code -->
<g id="WeekdayShort" class="1" fill="rgb(95,99,104)" font-size="14" font-family="Google Sans Text" font-style="normal" font-weight="500" aria-label="TUE" transform="matrix(2,0,0,2,50,20.66699981689453)" opacity="1" style="display: block;">
<g id="Title" class="1" fill="rgb(95,99,104)" font-size="14" font-family="Google Sans Text" font-style="normal" font-weight="500" aria-label="Weekly standup" transform="matrix(2,0,0,2,127,36.66699981689453)" opacity="1" style="display: block;">
<g id="Time" class="1" fill="rgb(255,255,255)" font-size="14" font-family="Google Sans Text" font-style="normal" font-weight="400" aria-label="11 AM – 12 PM" transform="matrix(2,0,0,2,109,76.66699981689453)" opacity="1" style="display: block;">


<!-- Fixed code -->
<g id="WeekdayShort1" class="1" fill="rgb(95,99,104)" font-size="14" font-family="Google Sans Text" font-style="normal" font-weight="500" aria-label="TUE" transform="matrix(2,0,0,2,50,20.66699981689453)" opacity="1" style="display: block;">
<g id="Title1" class="1" fill="rgb(95,99,104)" font-size="14" font-family="Google Sans Text" font-style="normal" font-weight="500" aria-label="Weekly standup" transform="matrix(2,0,0,2,127,36.66699981689453)" opacity="1" style="display: block;">
<g id="Time1" class="1" fill="rgb(255,255,255)" font-size="14" font-family="Google Sans Text" font-style="normal" font-weight="400" aria-label="11 AM – 12 PM" transform="matrix(2,0,0,2,109,76.66699981689453)" opacity="1" style="display: block;">
```

In this corrected version, I've added a unique suffix (`1`) to each `id` attribute to ensure that each element has a unique identifier. This should resolve the issue with multiple elements sharing the same `id` attribute, improving accessibility according to WCAG 2.1 guidelines.

description: Ensures the document has a main landmark
help: Document should have one main landmark
html: [['<html lang="en" data-cb-input-m="initial" data-cb-intent-m="initial" style="display: block;">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix all of the following:\n  Document does not have a main landmark']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<html lang="en" data-cb-input-m="initial" data-cb-intent-m="initial" style="display: block;">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( There should only be one 'main' landmark role per page. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
The given source code seems to be an HTML snippet that includes some data attributes and a style attribute, but it does not contain any actual HTML elements or a main landmark role. To fix the accessibility issue related to the mentioned success criteria according to WCAG 2.1, we need to ensure that there's only one main landmark role on the page. 

Here's an example of how you can modify the code to include a `main` element, which is considered the main landmark role in HTML:

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <!-- Meta tags and other head content here -->
    <!-- Ensure the 'main' element is the only main landmark role -->
</head>
<body>
    <main>
        <!-- Content that should be considered the main content of the page goes here -->
    </main>
    <!-- Other content, such as sidebars, navigation, or footers, should not contain a 'main' role -->
</body>
</html>
```

In this example, the `main` element is used to wrap the content that is considered the primary and main content of the page. Any other content on the page, such as sidebars, navigation, or footers, should not contain a `main` role, as specified by the success criteria.

Remember to place the `main` element in the appropriate part of your HTML document, ensuring that it logically encapsulates the main content of your page.

description: Ensures all page content is contained by landmarks
help: All page content should be contained by landmarks

prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "Skip to main content", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( A region element is not properly labeled with an aria-label or aria-labelledby attribute. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one: WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines) 2.1 Success Criteria #1.3.1 requires that information conveyed through the visual presentation of content must also be accessible through other senses, such as through text alternatives for non-text content. For a link or button, it's essential to provide a clear label that can be understood by assistive technology. The source code you provided is an HTML anchor tag (``) used for creating links. It includes attributes like `class`, `href`, `data-clog-click`, `data-clog-ui-element`, and `data-clog-ui-component`. These attributes seem to be related to some external script or framework (possibly a custom JavaScript library), but they do not provide a clear, accessible label for the button. To fix the accessibility issue according to the Success Criteria mentioned, the `aria-label` attribute should be added to the anchor tag to provide a clear, text-based label that describes the purpose of the button. Additionally, if the purpose can be conveyed more succinctly, consider using an `aria-labelledby` attribute to reference another element in the document that provides the label text. Here's the revised code: ```html Skip to main content ``` In this code, an `aria-label="Skip to main content"` attribute is added to the anchor tag, clearly indicating the purpose of the link. Additionally, a `span` element with `visually-hidden` class is added for screen readers. This invisible text provides an alternative label for those who cannot see the button (such as users with visual impairments) when the button is used in a keyboard-only workflow or in situations where the text might be too small to read. Remember to ensure that the `aria-label` text is concise and directly describes the function of the link, adhering to the guidelines for accessibility.

prompts_baseline_one:

<video title="A connected team discussing work in multiple channels in the Slack app" role="img" data-js-id="connectedness" loop="" muted="" playsinline="">
<video data-js-id="flexibility" title="A user starting a huddle and recording a video clip the Slack app" role="img" loop="" muted="" playsinline="">
<video data-js-id="speed" title="Using the Workday integration to quickly file an expense report in the Slack app" role="img" loop="" muted="" playsinline="">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( An ARIA role is used that is not allowed for the element. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 1.3.1 states that "Info and Relationships (Level A): All information necessary to understand and use the Web content is available to users, either on the Web page or through a link." One part of this criteria involves ensuring that the `role` attribute is used correctly, avoiding any that are not allowed for specific HTML elements.

In your code, each `video` element has an incorrect `role` attribute set to "img", which is not valid for the `video` element. The `role` attribute should be used to specify the semantics of the element, and for a `video` element, an appropriate `role` would typically be `presentation` or `movie`, depending on the content's role within the web page.

Here's how you can correct this issue:

```html
<video title="Team discussing work in the Slack app" role="presentation" data-js-id="hero" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" poster="https://a.slack-edge.com/2951054/marketing/img/homepage/e2e-prospects/animations/static/hero-product-ui.jpg">
<video title="A connected team discussing work in multiple channels in the Slack app" role="presentation" data-js-id="connectedness" loop="" muted="" playsinline="">
<video data-js-id="flexibility" title="A user starting a huddle and recording a video clip the Slack app" role="presentation" loop="" muted="" playsinline="">
<video data-js-id="speed" title="Using the Workday integration to quickly file an expense report in the Slack app" role="presentation" loop="" muted="" playsinline="">
```

By changing each `role` attribute to `"presentation"`, you ensure that the `video` elements are correctly identified as multimedia content, providing the necessary information for screen readers and other assistive technologies to understand the role of these elements within the document.

description: Ensures the document has at most one banner landmark
help: Document should not have more than one banner landmark
html: [['<header role="banner">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  Document has more than one banner landmark']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<header role="banner">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Multiple elements are assigned the 'banner' landmark role, which should be unique. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Certainly, to fix the accessibility issue with the given HTML snippet, we need to ensure that the 'banner' landmark role is unique as per the WCAG 2.1 guidelines. Here's how we can solve it:

Original Code:
```html
<header role="banner">...</header>
```

Fixed Code:
```html
<header role="banner" id="header-banner">...</header>
```

Explanation:
In HTML, roles like 'banner' are used to indicate the purpose of a section of the page. If there are multiple elements with the same role, it can cause confusion for assistive technologies (like screen readers) as they won't know which one to prioritize or focus on. To resolve this issue, we assign a unique identifier (ID) to each element with the 'banner' role. This unique ID ensures that each 'banner' has its own role, making it easier for assistive technologies to interpret and communicate the different sections of the page to the user. 

Here's the corrected code snippet:

```html
<header role="banner" id="header-banner">...</header>
```

In this example, the 'header' element is given the 'banner' role and an ID of 'header-banner'. If there are more 'banner' elements, they should follow the same pattern, i.e., have unique ID attributes like 'header-banner2', 'header-banner3', etc.

description: Landmarks should have a unique role or role/label/title (i.e. accessible name) combination
help: Ensures landmarks are unique
html: [['<header role="banner">', '<footer class="c-nav c-nav--footer">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  The landmark must have a unique aria-label, aria-labelledby, or title to make landmarks distinguishable', 'Fix any of the following:\n  The landmark must have a unique aria-label, aria-labelledby, or title to make landmarks distinguishable']]
prompts_baseline_one:
Given the following source code "<header role="banner">
<footer class="c-nav c-nav--footer">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Multiple landmarks of the same type should have unique and descriptive labels. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
The success criterion you mentioned from WCAG 2.1 applies to Landmarks. Landmarks are semantic elements used to group parts of the page into logical sections (such as header, navigation, content, footer, etc.). The issue with the given code is that there are multiple landmarks of the same type without unique and descriptive labels.

### Original Code:
```html
<header role="banner">
<footer class="c-nav c-nav--footer">
```

### Revised Code:
To fix the issue, we should provide unique labels for each landmark, ensuring that they are descriptive and meaningful. For example, you might have a header that's also a navigation, and a true footer. Here's a revised example:

```html
<header role="banner" aria-label="Top Navigation and Site Header">
<footer role="contentinfo" aria-label="Site Footer">
```

### Explanation:

1. **Header with ARIA Label**: The `header` element with a `role="banner"` is typically used for the top part of the page, which might include the logo, site name, and navigation. Adding `aria-label="Top Navigation and Site Header"` gives a clear indication of the role and content of this header segment.

2. **Footer with ARIA Label**: The `footer` element is usually used for the bottom part of the page, typically containing copyright information, legal notices, or additional links. Using `role="contentinfo"` and `aria-label="Site Footer"` helps clarify that this is indeed the footer section of the page.

### Additional Tips:

- **Consistent Landmark Usage**: Ensure all landmarks in your page are consistent in their naming and predictable in their roles. For example, use `role="navigation"` for every navigation section, not just the one that appears at the top.

- **Accessibility Audit**: Regularly perform accessibility audits on your website to ensure compliance with WCAG guidelines. Tools like WAVE, Axe, or automated testing can help identify such issues.

- **User Feedback**: Gather feedback from users with disabilities to understand if the labels you've chosen are clear and helpful.

By following these guidelines, you can ensure that your website not only meets the WCAG 2.1 standards but also provides a better user experience for all visitors.

description: Ensure all skip links have a focusable target
help: The skip-link target should exist and be focusable
html: [['Skip to main content']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  No skip link target']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "Skip to main content", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Page is missing a 'skip to content' link or the link is not functional. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one: The given source code seems to be an HTML anchor tag with a class and attributes that aim to create a skip-to-content link. This type of link helps users who use screen readers to skip to the main content of a webpage without having to navigate through non-essential elements. However, the code provided doesn't necessarily fulfill the WCAG 2.1 criteria for a 'skip to content' link if the following issues are present: 1. **Link is not functional**: Ensure that the `href` attribute leads to the main content of the page or to the first focusable element on the page, depending on the site's structure. 2. **Link is visible or has an appropriate text label**: The text content of the link should be meaningful to those who are using screen readers or navigating with keyboard-only input. 3. **Link is not used for navigating within the page**: A skip-to-content link should not be used as a way to navigate within a single page. Here is a revised version of the given code that addresses the issues and adheres to WCAG 2.1 guidelines: ```html Skip to main content ``` ### Explanation: - **`href="#main-content"`**: This attribute should point to the actual main content area of the page or to the first focusable element if there is no separate content section. Adjust the ID `"main-content"` to match the actual ID or selector of the first main content element. - **`tabindex="0"`**: This attribute allows the link to receive focus when navigating with a keyboard. It's important that links with the skip-to-content purpose are focusable. - **`aria-label="Skip to main content"`**: The `aria-label` attribute provides a description for the purpose of the link, which is crucial for accessibility as it is read by screen readers. Ensure that the element to which the skip-to-content link points (`#main-content`) actually exists and is the first major focusable element of the page. If the page does not have a separate main content area from the header or navigation, consider placing the link after the header or before the main content area. For further customization or specific implementations, consult the documentation of the framework or library where this code is used (if any), as additional attributes might be recommended or required.

description: Ensures <meta name="viewport"> does not disable text scaling and zooming
help: Zooming and scaling must not be disabled
html: [['<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,minimum-scale=1,maximum-scale=1,user-scalable=no">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  user-scalable=no on <meta> tag disables zooming on mobile devices']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,minimum-scale=1,maximum-scale=1,user-scalable=no">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Meta viewport tag is missing or not configured correctly for responsive design. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
The source code you've provided seems to be a `<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,minimum-scale=1,maximum-scale=1,user-scalable=no">` tag, which is used for optimizing the responsiveness of a website on mobile devices. However, it doesn't inherently cause an accessibility issue per se, but it's crucial for ensuring that the website is accessible across all devices, including those with assistive technologies.

Here are a few points to consider for improving accessibility related to this tag:

1. **Ensure Proper Scaling**: The `minimum-scale` and `maximum-scale` attributes restrict the user from zooming in or out beyond a certain level. This is helpful for controlling the layout on devices with high DPI screens, but it might not be necessary for everyone. Ensure this restriction is suitable for all users, especially those who need to zoom in to read content due to visual impairments.

2. **Responsive Design**: The `width=device-width` attribute sets the viewport width to the device's width. This is good practice, but make sure your website is truly responsive and adjusts its layout to fit various screen sizes without requiring horizontal scrolling.

3. **`initial-scale` Attribute**: Consider adding the `initial-scale` attribute to automatically set the initial zoom level. This helps users who might want to zoom in on the page for better visibility.

4. **Keyboard Navigation**: Ensure that the website is fully navigable via keyboard, which is crucial for users with motor impairments. This includes having a focus order that makes logical sense and does not require users to navigate through small elements due to the zoom level.

5. **Consistent Layouts**: Test your website across different devices and screen sizes to ensure that the layout remains consistent and readable. This includes things like text sizes, button sizes, and spacing.

Here's a revised version of the `<meta>` tag that includes an `initial-scale` attribute and might help improve accessibility:

```
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0, maximum-scale=1, minimum-scale=1, user-scalable=no">
```

However, to fully address accessibility concerns related to responsive design, you should also:
- Perform thorough testing on various devices and browser configurations, especially those with assistive technologies.
- Provide alternative text or descriptions for images and complex graphics that convey essential information.
- Ensure that all interactive elements are keyboard accessible and can be navigated using the tab key.
- Use semantic HTML to structure your content, which aids screen readers in understanding the document's structure.
- Implement sufficient color contrast to ensure readability for users with visual impairments.

Remember, accessibility is an ongoing process, and it's important to regularly review and update your website to ensure it remains accessible to all users.

prompts_baseline_one:
Given the following source code "<input name="input_1" id="input_1_1" type="text" value="" class="large" tabindex="100" aria-required="true" aria-invalid="false">
<input name="input_2" id="input_1_2" type="text" value="" class="large" tabindex="101" aria-required="true" aria-invalid="false">
<input name="input_3" id="input_1_3" type="text" value="" class="large" tabindex="102" aria-invalid="false">
<textarea name="input_4" id="input_1_4" class="textarea small" tabindex="103" aria-invalid="false" rows="10" cols="50"></textarea>
<input type="submit" id="gform_submit_button_1" class="gform_button button" value="Submit" tabindex="104" onclick="if(window["gf_submitting_1"]){return false;}  window["gf_submitting_1"]=true;  " onkeypress="if( event.keyCode == 13 ){ if(window["gf_submitting_1"]){return false;} window["gf_submitting_1"]=true;  jQuery("#gform_1").trigger("submit",[true]); }">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Tabindex value is either invalid or not used correctly. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
To ensure that the tabindex values are valid and used correctly, we need to check the current tabindex values and ensure they are not within an invalid range and that they are used consistently for elements that are tabbable. In the provided source code, each element has a tabindex attribute with a value from 100 to 104. These values seem to be within a valid range (from 0 to 32767) for tabindex attributes, but we need to ensure that:

1. **Tabindex values are not greater than the total number of tabbable elements**.
2. **Tabindex values are assigned to all elements that are meant to be focusable**.
3. **Tabindex values are used in a consistent manner**.

Here is the corrected version of the code with improved tabindex usage:

```html
<input name="input_1" id="input_1_1" type="text" value="" class="large" tabindex="0" aria-required="true" aria-invalid="false">
<input name="input_2" id="input_1_2" type="text" value="" class="large" tabindex="1" aria-required="true" aria-invalid="false">
<input name="input_3" id="input_1_3" type="text" value="" class="large" tabindex="2" aria-invalid="false">
<textarea name="input_4" id="input_1_4" class="textarea small" tabindex="3" aria-invalid="false" rows="10" cols="50"></textarea>
<input type="submit" id="gform_submit_button_1" class="gform_button button" tabindex="4" value="Submit" onclick="if(window['gf_submitting_1']){return false;} window['gf_submitting_1']=true; jQuery('#gform_1').trigger('submit',[true]);" onkeypress="if(event.keyCode == 13) { if(window['gf_submitting_1']){return false;} window['gf_submitting_1']=true; jQuery('#gform_1').trigger('submit',[true]); }">
```

### Explanation:

- **Tabindex values**: The tabindex values have been decremented from 100 to 4, ensuring they are within the valid range. Each element now has a tabindex value, starting from 0 for the first input field (assuming this is the first element in the tabbing sequence) up to 4. This sequence ensures that elements are focused in a logical order when navigating through the form with the keyboard.

- **Accessibility**: The `aria-required` attribute ensures that users are informed about required fields. The `aria-invalid` attribute is used to indicate that input is invalid (though it's not used in the example, it should be used properly depending on the validation state).

- **Focus and Keyboard Navigation**: By assigning unique tabindex values, the form elements are navigable using the keyboard, and the order aligns with the intended user flow.

### Additional Considerations:

- **Consistency**: Ensure that all tabbable elements in a form or application have tabindex values that follow a logical sequence that aligns with the natural flow of navigation and any page-specific requirements.

- **Focus Management**: Consider using JavaScript or frameworks to manage focus, especially for complex forms, to ensure that the focus is correctly managed as users navigate through the form.

By addressing these aspects, the provided HTML code now adheres more closely to WCAG 2.1 guidelines on tabindex values and improves overall accessibility for users navigating through the document with a keyboard.

prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<html lang="en">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( There should only be one 'main' landmark role per page. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
The source code provided `` does not include any landmark roles like `main`, `header`, `nav`, `aside`, `footer`, etc. The 'main' landmark role is important for indicating the primary content of a page, which is crucial for accessibility as screen reader users rely on these roles to navigate and understand the structure of a page. To fix the issue related to the success criteria for having only one 'main' landmark role per page, you should ensure that your HTML document includes only one element with the `main` landmark role, and that this element contains the primary content of your page. Here's how you can modify the code to ensure compliance with the WCAG 2.1 success criteria: ```html Your Page Title

Welcome to Our Site

This is the main content of your page.

Header Content (Optional)

``` In this example, the `main` role is used to encapsulate the primary content of the page. Additional elements like `header`, `nav`, `aside`, and `footer` can be used outside of the `main` role to provide supplementary content, but ensure that only one `main` role is used to clearly identify the main content area.

failureSummary:

  Form element does not have an implicit (wrapped) <label>
  Form element does not have an explicit <label>

prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<select class="sc-1x8wc7t-0 bBrjxy"><option value="en">English</option><option value="es">Español</option><option value="de-DE">Deutsch</option><option value="fr-FR">Français</option><option value="ja-JP">日本語</option><option value="pt-BR">Português</option><option value="ko-KR">한국어</option></select>", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Select element missing descriptive label. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 4.1.2 requires that every interactive control should have a label that describes its function. In the given HTML code, a `select` element seems to offer a dropdown list of language options, but it lacks a descriptive label that would inform users about its purpose. 

To fix this accessibility issue, we need to add a label for the `select` element. The label should be wrapped inside an `label` tag and should have a `for` attribute that matches the `id` of the `select` element if it has one, or otherwise, it should match the `name` attribute of the `select` element, if it is used.

Here's the corrected code:

```html
<label for="language-select">Choose a language:</label>
<select id="language-select" class="sc-1x8wc7t-0 bBrjxy">
    <option value="en">English</option>
    <option value="es">Español</option>
    <option value="de-DE">Deutsch</option>
    <option value="fr-FR">Français</option>
    <option value="ja-JP">日本語</option>
    <option value="pt-BR">Português</option>
    <option value="ko-KR">한국어</option>
</select>
```

In this code, I've added a `label` tag with the text "Choose a language:" that acts as a descriptive label for the `select` element. The `for` attribute of the `label` tag is set to "language-select", matching the `id` of the `select` element. This way, screen readers will announce the label when users interact with the `select` element, providing them with the necessary information about the purpose of the dropdown list.

prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<header class="sc-1ekvrxa-2 hKhOLf">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Multiple landmarks of the same type should have unique and descriptive labels. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
To address the accessibility issue related to the success criteria in Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1, where multiple landmarks of the same type should have unique and descriptive labels, you can modify the code as follows:

```html
<header class="sc-1ekvrxa-2" aria-label="Primary Navigation">
    <!-- Your navigation content here -->
</header>
```

Here's an explanation of the changes:

1. **Remove multiple classes**: The original code uses multiple classes (`sc-1ekvrxa-2 hKhOLf`) to define the header. Instead, use a single class for simplicity and clean-up.

2. **Add `aria-label` attribute**: The `aria-label` attribute is used to provide a label for an element that cannot be conveyed using text alone. In this case, we use it to give a descriptive label for the header that represents the primary navigation. For example, if this header contains links for navigation, you might use "Primary Navigation" as the label.

By doing this, you ensure that the header is properly labeled, making it more accessible to users who rely on assistive technologies like screen readers. The screen reader will now announce "Primary Navigation" when the user navigates to this header, helping them understand its purpose without needing to interact with it directly.

prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code " ", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Image missing alternative text. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one: WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines) 2.1 Success Criterion 1.1.1 suggests that "On text elements, text should either be provided or can be provided through text alternatives such as images of text, braille, or other alternatives." To address the accessibility issue related to images missing alternative text in the provided code, you can add alternative text descriptions to each image. These descriptions should provide a concise and meaningful summary of the image's content. Here's how you can modify the code to include alternative text: ```html ``` Remember to replace "Description of image" with a concise and meaningful summary of what each image represents. For example, if an image is a logo of a company, you could use the company name as the alternative text. If the image shows a scene, describe the scene briefly and accurately. This will help people who cannot see the images (such as those using screen readers) understand the content of the images.

description: Ensures the document has at most one banner landmark
help: Document should not have more than one banner landmark

failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  Document has more than one banner landmark']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<header class="sc-1ekvrxa-2 hKhOLf">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Multiple elements are assigned the 'banner' landmark role, which should be unique. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
WCAG 2.1 Success Criteria 3.1.1 requires that each landmark region (such as the body, content, banner, main, etc.) should have only one instance. Landmark roles like 'banner', 'content', 'main', etc., should be unique in the document.

In your provided code, there is no 'banner' role applied, but to fix the issue according to the criteria mentioned, you should ensure that no 'banner' role is assigned to any element if there's already another 'banner' role used elsewhere in the document. Here's an example of what your header might look like:

```html
<header class="sc-1ekvrxa-2 hKhOLf" role="region">
    <!-- Your banner content goes here -->
</header>
```

This example assumes that there's no other element with a 'banner' role in your document. If there is, you need to identify it and ensure it remains the only 'banner' role in your document.

If you're dealing with a situation where multiple banners are present, you should use descriptive and unique roles for each instead of 'banner', such as 'navigation', 'search', 'alert', etc., depending on the context. Here's an example:

```html
<header role="navigation">
    <!-- Navigation content goes here -->
</header>

<header role="search">
    <!-- Search content goes here -->
</header>
```

Remember, the accessibility role should correspond to the actual purpose of the element in the context.

prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<input type="search" autocomplete="off" class="bc-input bc-color-border-focus bc-color-base bc-color-background-base bc-color-border-base" value="" data-initial-value="" id="header-search" placeholder="Find your next great listen" name="keywords" aria-label="Search for an audiobook, newspaper, magazine and more" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-controls="ac-listbox" role="combobox">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( ARIA role missing required attribute. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Certainly! The issue with the given code is that the `role="combobox"` attribute is missing `aria-owns` attribute which is necessary for it to function properly as an accessible combobox. Additionally, the form associated with the search input might not have an `id` attribute, which could prevent the label from being correctly associated with the input field by screen readers. To fix the accessibility issues related to the success criteria (ARIA role missing required attribute), you can adjust the code as follows: ```html
``` And if you're using a dropdown or suggestion list, you might also need to add it: ```html
``` In the above code: - An `id` (`search-container`) is added to the container of the input field, which helps associate the label with the input field by screen readers. - The `aria-owns` attribute is added to the input field (`id="header-search"`) to associate it with the suggested list or dropdown (`id="ac-listbox"`). - The suggested list or dropdown is hidden and has an `aria-hidden="true"` attribute, which is important because it allows screen readers to skip over the element when navigating the page. This code should now better comply with WCAG 2.1 guidelines for accessibility.

description: Ensures elements with an ARIA role that require parent roles are contained by them
help: Certain ARIA roles must be contained by particular parents
html: [['<button type="button" data-role="none" role="tab" tabindex="0" id="slick-slide-control00" aria-controls="slick-slide00" aria-label="1 / 5" aria-selected="true">1</button>', '<button type="button" data-role="none" role="tab" tabindex="0" id="slick-slide-control10" aria-controls="slick-slide10" aria-label="1 / 5" aria-selected="true">1</button>']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  Required ARIA parent role not present: tablist', 'Fix any of the following:\n  Required ARIA parent role not present: tablist']]
prompts_baseline_one:
Given the following source code "<button type="button" data-role="none" role="tab" tabindex="0" id="slick-slide-control00" aria-controls="slick-slide00" aria-label="1 / 5" aria-selected="true">1</button>
<button type="button" data-role="none" role="tab" tabindex="0" id="slick-slide-control10" aria-controls="slick-slide10" aria-label="1 / 5" aria-selected="true">1</button>", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( ARIA role missing required parent. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Certainly. The issue you've mentioned is related to the Success Criterion 4.1.2 (Role) of WCAG 2.1, which states that all UI components must have a suitable ARIA role specified, and these roles should be consistent with their meanings and context within the application. The `<button>` elements have ARIA roles (`role="tab"` and `role="none"`), but the parent elements are missing corresponding ARIA roles that would provide a clear context for these buttons.

Here's how you can fix the issue:

```html
<nav role="tablist">
    <button type="button" data-role="none" role="tab" tabindex="0" id="slick-slide-control00" aria-controls="slick-slide00" aria-label="1 / 5" aria-selected="true">1</button>
    <button type="button" data-role="none" role="tab" tabindex="0" id="slick-slide-control10" aria-controls="slick-slide10" aria-label="1 / 5" aria-selected="true">1</button>
</nav>
```

In this solution:
- I've wrapped the buttons in a `nav` element with `role="tablist"`. This role is appropriate for a list of tab-like items, such as pagination controls, which is what the buttons in your example seem to represent.
- The `nav` element provides a meaningful context for the buttons, making it clear that they are part of a navigation component.
- The buttons themselves retain their ARIA roles (`role="tab"`), which are now correctly associated with a parent role.

This change should resolve the ARIA role missing required parent issue, aligning with the WCAG 2.1 Success Criteria.

    • ", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Element with 'presentation' role contains child elements with semantic roles, causing a conflict. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Certainly, to resolve the issue related to the failure of WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 1.3.1 (Label and指示器), which applies to elements with a 'presentation' role containing child elements with semantic roles, you should ensure that only elements with semantic meaning are used within roles that are intended for decorative purposes. Here's a corrected version of your code: ```html
    • ``` Here's the reasoning behind each change: 1. **Remove the 'presentation' role**: The `role="presentation"` attribute should not be present if the element is intended to carry meaning, such as a label or control. In this case, the button that represents a visual control for a slide should not have this role. 2. **Use semantic roles**: The buttons are now given the role of "tab" and appropriate aria-labels, which reflect their purpose as navigational elements. This helps screen reader users understand the function of these buttons. 3. **Remove redundant 'presentation' elements**: The `role="presentation"` elements used in the original code to hide content visually are redundant when using `aria-hidden="true"`. These can be removed to simplify the HTML structure. By making these changes, the code now better adheres to the principle of providing clear, meaningful roles and labels, which is essential for accessibility.

Given the following source code "<ul class="slick-dots slick-dots-inverse" role="tablist" style="">
<ul class="slick-dots slick-dots-inverse" role="tablist" style="">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( ARIA role missing required children. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
WCAG 2.1 Success Criteria 4.1.2 requires that each role has a correct and appropriate set of semantics according to its meaning, and that roles are nested correctly. The provided source code seems to include an `ul` element with a class `slick-dots slick-dots-inverse` and a `role="tablist"`. However, to accommodate accessibility, it's important to ensure that all the elements that the `role="tablist"` attribute is intended for are actually nested within this `ul` and are of appropriate roles. In the case of a `tablist`, it's typically used to group a set of `tab` items, each of which is typically represented by a `button` element. In addition, each `tab` item should have a `role="tab"` attribute. Here's the corrected code: ```html
``` In this revised code: - Each `li` element within the `ul` is a `presentation` role, which generally indicates that this is an item that is visually presented in a list, but it's not interactive on its own. - Each `button` element within the `li` is a `tab` role. This role tells the screen reader software that this is a clickable item that can be activated to switch to the corresponding tab content. - The `aria-controls` attribute on each `button` is used to link it to the corresponding tab content by ID. This allows screen reader users to know where they will navigate when they activate the tab. - The `aria-selected` attribute is used to show the currently active tab. This attribute should be dynamically updated when the user activates a different tab. Remember that the actual tab content should also be marked with `role="tabpanel"` if it's meant to be associated with the tab, and it should have an appropriate ID that matches the `aria-controls` attribute of the tab button. This approach ensures that the tab functionality is accessible to users who rely on assistive technologies like screen readers.

description: Ensures all elements with a role attribute use a valid value
help: ARIA roles used must conform to valid values
html: [['']]
failureSummary: [['Fix all of the following:\n  Role must be one of the valid ARIA roles: pagedescription']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Invalid or inappropriate ARIA role assigned to an element. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
The source code you've provided seems to be referring to a link or button that has some accessibility instructions embedded within the role attribute (`role="pagedescription"`). According to the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1, the use of `role` attributes should be done appropriately to convey the intended role of the element to assistive technologies.

The issue here is that the `role` attribute value `pagedescription` is not a valid role value defined in the ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) specification. Valid role values might include `button`, `link`, `alert`, etc., depending on the element's function. 

To fix this issue, you need to replace `role="pagedescription"` with a valid ARIA role that matches the function of the element. Since the provided code seems to be for a link or button that likely serves as a navigation element, the most appropriate role would likely be `button`.

Here is the corrected code:

```html
<button id="aging-total-page" aria-label="欢迎进入 百度一下，你就知道，盲人用户进入读屏幕模式请按快捷键Ctrl加Alt加R；阅读详细操作说明请按快捷键Ctrl加Alt加问号键." tabindex="0" href="javascript:void(0)">
</button>
```

In this corrected code:

- The role attribute has been removed, since it's not necessary for a button.
- The button is now marked with the `button` role through the `role` attribute in the ARIA suite (`aria-role` attribute), which is obsolete as of ARIA 1.1 but is still commonly used for backward compatibility.
- The `aria-label` attribute provides a description of the button, which is crucial for screen reader users to understand the purpose of the button.
- The `tabindex="0"` attribute maintains the ability for keyboard navigation, assuming that the element is meant to be interacted with via keyboard.

This revised code should be more accessible to users of assistive technologies.

To fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria of "Form control missing associated label" according to WCAG 2.1, you need to ensure that each form control has an associated label that describes its purpose. This can be achieved by using the `label` element and properly associating it with the form control using the `for` attribute in the `label` element and the `id` attribute in the form control.

```html
<label for="kw">
```

In the modified code:

1. I've wrapped the `input` element inside a `label` element.
2. I've added an `id` attribute to the `input` element as `kw`.
3. I've added a `for` attribute to the `label` element with the value `kw`, which associates the label with the input control.

Now, the input control is associated with a label that describes its purpose, which helps improve accessibility for users who rely on screen readers or other assistive technologies.

Here's how you can fix this accessibility issue: ### Revised HTML Code: ```html ``` ### Explanation of Changes: 1. **First Image (`img` Element):** - Updated the `alt` attribute to include a descriptive text ("Baidu Logo - New Image"). This text will help screen readers convey the purpose of the image to users who are visually impaired. 2. **Second Image (`img` Element):** - Added an `alt` attribute with descriptive text ("Baidu QR Code"). This text will help screen readers convey the purpose of this image as well. ### Additional Recommendations: - Ensure that the text within the `alt` attributes is concise and accurately describes the content or function of the image. Avoid using generic text such as "image" or "picture" as they do not provide meaningful information to users who cannot see the images. - Consider using ARIA labels or roles (`aria-label` or `aria-labelledby`) for images that are part of complex documents or need more specific context, especially if the `alt` text is not sufficient. - Keep in mind that images that are purely decorative and do not carry any text or information should ideally be made non-clickable or use the `aria-hidden="true"` attribute to ensure assistive technologies ignore them. By implementing these changes, you improve the accessibility of your web content for users who rely on assistive technologies.

prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<html>", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( HTML element missing lang attribute. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Certainly! To fix the accessibility issue related to the missing `lang` attribute in the provided HTML code, you need to add a valid `lang` attribute to the `<html>` element. The `lang` attribute specifies the language of the content.

Here's the updated code with the `lang` attribute added:

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>Document Title</title>
</head>
<body>
    <!-- Your content goes here -->
</body>
</html>
```

In this example, I've added a `lang="en"` attribute to the `<html>` element, assuming the content is in English. You should replace "en" with the appropriate ISO 639-1 language code for the content of your website.

Adding a `lang` attribute helps screen readers and other assistive technologies understand the language of the content, which can improve accessibility for users who rely on these tools.

description: Ensures the document has at most one contentinfo landmark
help: Document should not have more than one contentinfo landmark

failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  Document has more than one contentinfo landmark']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<footer class="footer" id="globalfooter">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Multiple elements are assigned the 'contentinfo' landmark role, which should be unique. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Certainly, the success criteria mentioned refers to WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines) 2.1, specifically the guideline 1.3.1 "Info and Relationships". This guideline states that information conveyed by non-text content must have a text alternative that serves the equivalent purpose, and relationships between pieces of information must be revealed through both structure and content. Moreover, it includes rule 1.3.2 "Labeling", which ensures that all interactive elements have labels that make their function understandable.

The source code you provided appears to assign the role 'contentinfo' to an element, which is intended to represent information about the entire content of the document. A contentinfo role is not allowed to be used more than once within a single document as per the ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) specification.

To fix the accessibility issue, you can remove or modify the 'contentinfo' role from all elements and use proper ARIA roles where necessary. For instance, if you need to mark certain sections as a footer, you can use the 'footer' role as you have already done in your example, which is appropriate according to ARIA guidelines.

Here's the source code revised to remove the 'contentinfo' role:

```html
<footer class="footer" id="globalfooter">
    <!-- Footer content -->
</footer>
```

In this corrected code, I've removed the 'contentinfo' role because it's not necessary and was violating the rule of assigning each role exactly once in a document. The 'footer' role is sufficient for denoting the document's footer section.

Remember that ensuring a document has a single 'contentinfo' role is important for accessibility, as it helps screen reader users understand the structure of the page. However, in this case, since the role 'footer' is used appropriately, there's no need for a 'contentinfo' role.

prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<a href="https://www.barclays.co.uk/current-accounts/service-quality-metrics#ni" class="no-text-decoration" data-component-type="Image">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Link missing descriptive text. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Certainly! The code you provided is a hyperlink that appears to link to some information about service quality metrics, particularly those related to the customer's location in Northern Ireland, hosted on the Barclays UK website. The issue is that there is no alternative text (a.k.a. "alt text") provided for this link, which is necessary for users who rely on screen readers to navigate websites. Screen readers need text descriptions to convey the link's purpose to their users.

To fix this accessibility issue, you should add a title attribute to the anchor tag (`<a>`) that describes the content or purpose of the link. Here's how you can modify the code:

```html
<a href="https://www.barclays.co.uk/current-accounts/service-quality-metrics#ni" class="no-text-decoration" data-component-type="Image" title="View Service Quality Metrics for Northern Ireland">
```

In this updated code, the `title` attribute has been added with the text "View Service Quality Metrics for Northern Ireland". This provides a clear description of what the link leads to, which screen readers can read out to users, enhancing their understanding and navigation of the website.

Remember, while the `title` attribute serves as a textual alternative for links, it's also a good practice to ensure that the content within the link (if any) is also accessible to screen readers. In cases where the link text is essential, keep it descriptive and meaningful as well.

responses_baseline_one:
To fix the accessibility issue related to the missing `lang` attribute within the provided HTML source code, you need to add the `lang` attribute to the `html` element. The `lang` attribute specifies the language of the content, which is important for accessibility as it helps screen readers interpret the content correctly and provide a better user experience.

Here's how you can add the `lang` attribute:

```html
<html class="b-header--black--white b-pw-1280 b-reith-sans-font id-svg flexbox flexboxlegacy flexwrap svg inlinesvg fontface csscolumns csscolumns-width csscolumns-span csscolumns-fill csscolumns-gap csscolumns-rule csscolumns-rulecolor csscolumns-rulestyle csscolumns-rulewidth csscolumns-breakbefore csscolumns-breakafter csscolumns-breakinside cssgradients supports cssfilters csstransforms generatedcontent b-reith-sans-loaded bbcdotcom" lang="en" style="">
```

In this case, `en` stands for English. You should replace `en` with the appropriate language code for the content you are providing. For example, `es` for Spanish, `fr` for French, etc.

Adding the `lang` attribute to the `html` element is crucial for ensuring that the content can be properly interpreted by assistive technologies like screen readers. This can make your website more accessible to people who rely on such technologies to navigate the web.

prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<iframe name="edr_l_first" id="edr_l_first" frameborder="0" src="https://edigitalsurvey.com/l.php?id=INS-vt29-666188954&v=7291&x=1280&y=720&d=24&c=null&ck=1&p=%2F&fu=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.com%2F&xdm=edr&xdm_o=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.com&xdm_c=edr0" scrolling="no">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Frame missing or has non-descriptive title attribute. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
To address the accessibility issue related to the success criteria "Frame missing or has non-descriptive title attribute" as per WCAG 2.1, you should add a `title` attribute to the `iframe` element that provides a brief and descriptive label for the content within the frame. This will assist users, especially those using screen readers, in understanding what the content in the frame represents.

Here's the corrected code with the added `title` attribute:

```html
<iframe name="edr_l_first" id="edr_l_first" frameborder="0" src="https://edigitalsurvey.com/l.php?id=INS-vt29-666188954&v=7291&x=1280&y=720&d=24&c=null&ck=1&p=%2F&fu=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.com%2F&xdm=edr&xdm_o=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.com&xdm_c=edr0" scrolling="no" title="Digital Survey Landing Page">
</iframe>
```

The `title` attribute text should be a concise and meaningful description of the content within the frame. Modify the text as necessary to accurately reflect the purpose or subject of the iframe's content. For example, if the page is meant to collect survey responses about the BBC, you might use a title like "BBC Survey".

``` In this revised code: - A new `div` container is added around the content to ensure logical grouping, which helps screen readers navigate the content more effectively. - An `h2` element with a class "landmark" is added to serve as a unique and descriptive label for this section of the navigation. This label should be descriptive enough to give context about the type of content or functionality that the links within this section provide. - The `ul` list element remains for the links, but ensure that any additional links are added inside this list. This solution ensures that each "nav" landmark has a unique and descriptive label, improving the accessibility for users who rely on screen readers or other assistive technologies.

prompts_baseline_one:
Given the following source code "<aside class="tile--icon">
<aside class="tile--icon">
<aside class="tile--icon">
<aside class="tile--icon">
<aside class="tile--icon">
<aside class="tile--icon">
<aside class="tile--icon">
<aside class="tile--icon">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( The 'complementary' landmark role should be assigned only to a top-level element. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
In the given source code, there are multiple elements with the `class="tile--icon"`. To fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria mentioned (The 'complementary' landmark role should be assigned only to a top-level element), you can assign a unique `id` to each `aside` element and then use the `role` attribute to indicate the complementary relationship. However, it's important to note that the term 'complementary' is not directly related to any landmark role in WCAG 2.1, but typically it can refer to elements that provide supplementary information or actions on a webpage.

Assuming that each `<aside class="tile--icon">` element is meant to be a complementary part of the page, you can modify the code like this:

```html
<section id="tileContainer">
    <aside class="tile--icon" id="tile1">
        <!-- Content for tile 1 -->
    </aside>
    <aside class="tile--icon" id="tile2">
        <!-- Content for tile 2 -->
    </aside>
    <!-- Repeat for other tiles -->
</section>
```

Then you can use JavaScript or ARIA roles to clarify the relationship between the tiles and the container. For example, you can add an `aria-labelledby` attribute to each `aside` element linking to the container's `id`:

```html
<aside class="tile--icon" id="tile1" aria-labelledby="tileContainer">
    <!-- Content for tile 1 -->
</aside>
```

This way, it's clear that `tile1` is a part of the `tileContainer`, and screen readers can understand this relationship when navigating through the page.

Remember that the actual landmark role that needs to be applied depends on the structure of your page and what `aside` elements are meant to represent. For example, if they are meant to be headers (`role="header"`), regions (`role="region"`), main content (`role="main"`), etc., you should assign the appropriate landmark role based on the content and structure of your page.

[['

description: Ensures role attribute has an appropriate value for the element
help: ARIA role should be appropriate for the element
html: [['<select aria-labelledby="global-footer-select-label" class="eds-field-styled__input eds-field-styled__select" role="listbox" id="global-footer-select" name="global-footer-select">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  ARIA role listbox is not allowed for given element']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<select aria-labelledby="global-footer-select-label" class="eds-field-styled__input eds-field-styled__select" role="listbox" id="global-footer-select" name="global-footer-select">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( An ARIA role is used that is not allowed for the element. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Based on the given source code snippet, the issue you're referring to is related to WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 1.3.1 (Info and Relationships), which states that "Information and relationships in data should be presented in a way that can be perceived." In the context of ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) roles, this criterion requires that:

> "The role attribute specifies the role of an element as understood by an assistive technology (AT). The attribute value must be an ARIA role that is appropriate for the element's purpose."

The issue in the provided source code is that the element is using a role of "listbox," which is appropriate for a "select" element. However, the problem might be more related to the use of `aria-labelledby` instead of `aria-describedby`. `aria-labelledby` should be used when the label text is split across multiple elements, or when the label text is not immediately adjacent to the element. If the `label` element is directly associated with this `select` element, then `aria-labelledby` attribute usage might not be necessary unless there are specific cases like the label text is spread across multiple elements.

The WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 4.1.2 (Name, Role, Value) also states that:
> "For an interactive component, the name and role can be determined programmatically."

Given this, we need to ensure that the `select` element has a meaningful `role` attribute and that it has an `aria-labelledby` attribute if there's a label that needs to be identified beyond the regular HTML `<label>` attribute. 

To fix the issue:

1. **Check Label Association:** Ensure that the `<label>` element directly associated with this `select` element has an `id` attribute that matches the `aria-labelledby` attribute value.

Original:
```html
<label for="global-footer-select">Footer Select</label>
<select aria-labelledby="global-footer-select-label" ...>
```

Expected:
```html
<label for="global-footer-select-label">Footer Select</label>
<select id="global-footer-select" aria-labelledby="global-footer-select-label" ...>
```

2. **Remove Unnecessary ARIA Attribute:** If the label is directly associated and there's no need for `aria-labelledby`, you can remove it to ensure that the role is correctly applied.

```html
<!-- Remove aria-labelledby if it's not necessary -->
<select id="global-footer-select" name="global-footer-select">...</select>
```

3. **Ensure Semantic Markup:** If possible, consider using semantic HTML elements such as `<datalist>` or `<optgroup>` and `<option>` to enhance accessibility and potentially avoid the use of `aria-labelledby` altogether.

```html
<label for="global-footer-select">Footer Select:</label>
<input type="list" id="global-footer-select" list="footer-options">
<datalist id="footer-options">
  <option value="Option 1">
  <option value="Option 2">
</datalist>
```

Remember that the goal is not just to satisfy accessibility standards but to create a more user-friendly experience for everyone, including those with disabilities.

prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "Cookies Policy", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Active elements share the same id attribute. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
The source code you provided links to the Facebook Cookies Policy webpage, but it doesn't demonstrate an HTML element with an `id="cpn-pv-link"`. To address the accessibility issue related to the success criterion about "Active elements share the same id attribute", let's assume this id is attached to a specific element on the webpage you're referring to. Here's an example of how you can modify the code to ensure all elements with the same id are correctly handled:

```html
<!-- Assuming the element with id "cpn-pv-link" is a button -->
<button id="cpn-pv-link" onclick="redirectToCookiesPolicy()">
    <!-- button text -->
</button>

<script>
    function redirectToCookiesPolicy() {
        window.open("https://www.facebook.com/privacy/policies/cookies", "_blank");
    }
</script>
```

In this example:

1. An HTML `button` element is used as an example of an active element.
2. The element's `id` attribute is set to "cpn-pv-link".
3. An `onclick` attribute is added to the button, which calls a JavaScript function named `redirectToCookiesPolicy`. This function opens the URL in a new browser tab or window depending on the `target="_blank"` attribute.

To ensure all active elements share the same `id` attribute, you would need to identify all elements that are intended to trigger the same functionality and apply the same `id` attribute to them. This ensures that when any of these elements is interacted with, the same behavior is triggered.

Remember, this is just a simplified example, and actual implementation might require more complex interactions depending on the context of your application.

For broader application, you might also need to ensure that all interactive elements (like links, buttons, etc.) have unique and meaningful IDs, or consider using a different attribute like `aria-labelledby` if they share the same functionality but need different text descriptions.

Back to Top Count me in!
For restaurants For drivers For corporate accounts Become an Affiliate For campuses & hotels

", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( A region element is not properly labeled with an aria-label or aria-labelledby attribute. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
To address the accessibility issue related to WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 1.3.1 (Info and Relationships), which states that "Information and relationships within and between elements must be presented in a meaningful way," we need to ensure that every region within the HTML document is properly labeled. In this case, the issue seems to be with the lack of an `aria-label` or `aria-labelledby` attribute for certain elements. Let's correct this by adding the necessary attributes: ### Code Modification: Here is the modified version of the code where I've added `aria-label` attributes to the elements that were missing them: ```html

Get food delivery and more

``` ### Explanation: 1. **Adding `aria-label`**: For elements that need a label (like input fields, buttons, etc.), an `aria-label` attribute is added. This attribute directly provides a label that describes the purpose of the element. 2. **Ensuring Meaningful Labels**: Ensure that the label provided is meaningful and descriptive of the purpose of the element. For example, "Search Address" describes the function of the `input` element. 3. **Consistency**: Apply this to all elements that lack an appropriate label, making sure that each element has a relevant and meaningful label. ### Additional Considerations: - **Screen Reader Compatibility**: Ensure that the added `aria-label` attributes are compatible with screen readers. Screen readers should interpret these labels correctly. - **Responsive Design**: With responsive design elements like `.u-center-background` and `.u-hidden-sm--down`, ensure that the labels are visible and accessible at all screen sizes. - **Review Other Elements**: While focusing on the provided snippet, it's important to review the entire document for other elements that might also need `aria-label` or `aria-labelledby` attributes for proper screen reader accessibility. By making these changes, you ensure that the HTML document adheres to the WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 1.3.1, making it more accessible to people with disabilities, especially those who rely on screen readers.

description: Ensures <meta name="viewport"> does not disable text scaling and zooming
help: Zooming and scaling must not be disabled
html: [['<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,initial-scale=1,maximum-scale=1,user-scalable=no">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  user-scalable=no on <meta> tag disables zooming on mobile devices']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,initial-scale=1,maximum-scale=1,user-scalable=no">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Meta viewport tag is missing or not configured correctly for responsive design. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
The source code you provided includes a `meta` tag that is used to manage viewport settings for responsive design on a webpage. It appears to be correctly configured according to the criteria you've mentioned: the viewport is set to adjust its width to fit the device's screen, the initial zoom level is set to 1 (meaning it won't zoom in or out upon loading), the maximum scale is also set to 1 (limiting zoom to the initial scale), and user scalability is disabled (preventing users from manually adjusting the zoom).

The code snippet you provided is:

```html
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,initial-scale=1,maximum-scale=1,user-scalable=no">
```

This tag is already compliant with the WCAG 2.1 guidelines related to responsive design (Success Criterion 1.4.4) as it ensures that the webpage will adapt to different screen sizes without requiring users to manually adjust the zoom level.

If you're encountering issues related to accessibility, it's important to consider the following aspects:

1. **Text Size and Readability:** Ensure that the text is readable and accessible at the default zoom level. This might require responsive CSS styles that adjust font sizes based on screen size.

2. **Navigation and Content Scrolling:** Ensure that navigation elements are accessible and that content can be easily scrolled without requiring excessive manual zooming or scrolling.

3. **Contrast:** Check that the text and background contrast meets the WCAG 2.1 contrast ratio requirements (at least 4.5:1 for normal text).

4. **Keyboard Accessibility:** Ensure that all interactive elements can be accessed and operated using only a keyboard.

5. **Screen Reader Compatibility:** Make sure that screen readers can correctly interpret and read out the content, especially important for labels, headings, and form elements.

Here's an example of how you could adjust your CSS to ensure text is responsive and readable across different devices:

```css
body {
  font-size: 16px; /* or any default font size */
  line-height: 1.5; /* or any line-height that improves readability */
}

@media (max-width: 600px) {
  body {
    font-size: calc(16px + (20 - 16) * ((100vw - 300px) / (600 - 300))); /* Media query for smaller screens */
  }
}
```

In this example, the `body` font size adjusts dynamically based on the viewport width for devices with smaller screens, helping text to remain readable without manual zooming.

If you're facing specific issues with accessibility despite having the viewport tag in place, it would be helpful to review the complete HTML document and CSS styles to identify other potential issues that could affect accessibility.

description: Ensures the document has a main landmark
help: Document should have one main landmark
html: [['<html lang="en">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix all of the following:\n  Document does not have a main landmark']]
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<html lang="en">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( There should only be one 'main' landmark role per page. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
The code snippet you provided is just the HTML `<html>` tag with the `lang="en"` attribute, which indicates that the content is in English. This does not contain any "landmark roles" that would require being refactored for accessibility purposes according to WCAG 2.1 criteria.

Landmark roles are used within HTML to group content hierarchically and provide roles such as `main`, `header`, `nav`, `footer`, etc. to make it easier for assistive technologies to navigate the document. According to WCAG 2.1, there should only be one `main` landmark role per page.

Here's an example of how you might correct your code to address this issue:

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>Example Website</title>
</head>
<body>
    <main>
        <!-- Content that should be the primary focus of the page goes here -->
    </main>
    <!-- Additional content goes below the main landmark role -->
</body>
</html>
```

In this example, the `main` role is used once to encapsulate the content that should be the primary focus of the page. Any additional content that doesn't need to be grouped under a `main` role can go outside of the `main` element.

Remember, the structure of your HTML document, including the usage of landmark roles, should follow the guidelines of WCAG 2.1 to ensure accessibility for all users.

United States

prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<input type="search" name="q" id="q" title="Search all IEEE websites" placeholder="Search all IEEE websites" class="required form-control">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( ARIA elements share the same id. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
The given source code contains a field with an `id` attribute of "q". This field is an input type of "search", and it is given an `aria-labelledby` attribute that references the same "q" id. This violates the accessibility guideline of not allowing ARIA elements to share the same ID. 

To correct this issue according to WCAG 2.1 guidelines, you should assign a unique `id` to your ARIA label element, and reference that unique id in the `aria-labelledby` attribute of your input element. 

Assuming you have a label element with the text "Search all IEEE websites", your code would look something like this:

```html
<label for="search-label">Search all IEEE websites</label>
<input type="search" id="search-input" name="q" aria-labelledby="search-label" class="required form-control">
```

In this case, you've given the label element a `for` attribute that matches the `id` of the input element, which is now unique. You've also updated the `aria-labelledby` attribute of the input element to reference the unique `id` of the label element instead of sharing the same `id`.

``` In this example, the `main` role is used only once to encapsulate the primary content of the page. Other content such as navigation, sidebars, or footers, which are not considered part of the main content, are placed outside the `main` element or in separate elements. If you have multiple sections that you consider "main," choose one section to be the main content and make sure that the others are not marked with the `main` role. This helps ensure that assistive technologies can identify and present the main content correctly to users with disabilities.

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">

    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>Example Page</title>
</head>
<body>
    <!-- Your content here -->
</body>
</html>
```

In this example, I've added the `lang` attribute to the `html` element with the value "en", which stands for English. You should replace "en" with the appropriate language code for your content. This will help improve the accessibility of your document by providing information about the language used, which can be used by assistive technologies like screen readers.

``` ### Explanation: - **`aria-label`**: This attribute is directly attached to the link element (``), and it describes the role of the link itself. Here’s a solution to correct this issue: First, let's make sure that the `ol` element can be tabbed to and receive keyboard focus. This can be achieved by adding a `role` attribute to the `ol` element to indicate that it is a list, and maybe also setting a `tabindex` attribute to ensure it's focusable. ```html

If the scrollable region is a part of a more complex UI component (e.g., a contenteditable div or a complex component built with JavaScript), you might need to add additional JavaScript or use a framework that provides better control over accessibility. Here's an example of how you might handle the scrollable region in a more robust way: ```html
    ``` In this example, the scrollable content is encapsulated in a `div` with a class of `.scrollable-content`. The `ol` inside this div can now be tabbed to and focused, as it has the `tabindex="0"` attribute. The `overflow-y: auto;` property allows the content to scroll vertically when it exceeds the height specified in the `height` attribute. Remember, this is just a basic example. For more complex scenarios, you might need to use JavaScript or a library/framework like React, Vue, or Angular to ensure that the scrollable region is not only visible but also accessible to keyboard users.
